content: I'd like to add cover art if there are no objections.

It's a bit weird that you've got a test for negative values, but no actual specification there. (doesn't say "signed" anywhere)

Also strange that the registers have a specified width, if there's no verified overflow/underflow.

Very nice problem, however I agree with nicola that it's too complex for Clash of Code for most participants. I really think there should be an "expert" mode of CoC with puzzles like this, and maybe this was the case with "Coffee break" clashes but they're no longer there, probably because of low popularity.
Upvoted but too long for a five-minute CoC.

I really like the idea and took the time to solve it ! But in my opinion the JNE should deserve more exemples to insure the solvability under 15 minutes.  It took me some times to understand the whole thing, may be the hangover is not helping my process of though :p. Yet amazing work and this one should really deserve it place in the arena : D. Still amaze me what simple instructions can accomplish :).

Thank you for your wonderful feedback! :)
I've added a full example, so that one can better understand what the JNE instruction does. In the beginning I wanted to add even more instructions, but even with only those four time might get scarce. Anyway, I'm glad that you liked it and even if it doesn't make it, I might rework and extend it to a community puzzle. :)

You're right, "signed" is not implied in every language for "integer", I'll add it.

My intention for giving the register width was that people can use the according integer type (i.e. short) and don't have to worry about over- and underflows, as it is stated directly before the list of instructions . Do you think that it is more confusing than helping?

Yeah, I found that confusing.
In a real microprocessor manual, the bitwidth is a property of the register, and signedness a property of the operations (though it usually only really makes sense for multiplication and division, which aren't present here).
And then it matters for reading the initial abcd values and printing them back in the end.

If I understood the spirit right, in your case I'd suggest:
- Statement section
  * a, b, c, d: integer registers
- Constraints section:
  * -2^15 <= a,b,c,d < 2^15
  * Overflow and underflow behavior is unspecified (and untested).

And, arguably more importantly, have negative values in the example.

Thank you for your feedback!

I've added your suggestions and changed the full example to have a negative value.

You're right about the bits in the register not saying anything about signedness, it's the operations (JA and JG often give me a headache when just reading the flags) that make the difference. I tried to keep it simple and understandable for people who don't know much about processors or assembly in general, but your suggestions make it clearer and better.
